data.title: New: GuiBitmapBarCtrl
data.body:
clipped bitmap. by default clips the right hand side based on (the percent entry/100).
options:
vertical clips the bottom
flipClip inverts direction (so vertical off would remove bits from the left, vertical on from the top)

data.title: raycast division safety
data.body: - corrects issues with awesomium and the guionobject resources relating to WYSIWYG casts.

data.title: Projection matrices wrong in OpenGL
data.body:
Recently I told Azaezel the projection matrices were wrong in OpenGL, they did not look the same as in DirectX, then he committed a fix for them:
https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/commit/223e9a8264820b2f64de28cbb131e881b03fe4be
It solved the issue, but later I found out, that it breaks shadows in OpenGL, then later Jeff rolled it back, it fixed the shadows, but the projection matrices are wrong again:
https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/commit/bc9033da2e51cbeb7722157d6c4da03cd29f002e

It is not that big of an issue, but it makes that the clipping distance is wrong. In my example, I have a player that uses realistic first person view, so it uses the full model in first person, but you can see pieces of the helmet if you look up, while it is not visible in DirectX rendering.

For reference it is the "nearClip" value in theLevelInfo object in your mission.
By default it is set to 0.1 for each level, which is a good distance, but if you switch to OpenGL it behaves like it would have been set to 0.05, so about half the value as in DirectX.

data.title: No shadows in OpenGL
data.body:
I noticed that there are no shadows in OpenGL render mode.
The issue was not always there, it only recently got introduced for some people after some graphics driver update.
No idea when exactly the issue appeared, I do not use OpenGL that often, so maybe some people can switch to OpenGL and test it as well.

data.title: TorqueScript Case Insensitivity in Linux
data.body: Seems the engine saves strings at the first case it encounters them.  Any later references with different case gets ignored.  This causes issues in case-sensitive linux.

http://forums.torque3d.org/viewtopic.php?f=2&t=665

data.title: Add DEB and RPM package support
data.body:
CMake can be used to build DEB packages via the [CPack](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.5/module/CPackDeb.html) module. A DEB package would greatly simplify the distribution of Torque3D to Linux users. In fact, if we can build a DEB package for Torque3D, I can submit the package for inclusion into the official Debian repository, thus allowing Debian/Ubuntu users to simply perform a `apt-get install torque3d` to automagically install Torque3D with all necessary dependencies.

Adding DEB package support shouldn't be that difficult. I implemented a small 15-line [proof-of-concept on my local fork](https://github.com/vilhelmgray/Torque3D/commit/c8818228c1124fc3018f43db9f04f24d50f77f5d). Essentially, we create a new **CPackConfig.cmake** file where we configure the package, and add `include(CPackConfig.cmake)` at the end of **CMakeLists.txt**; that's pretty much the bare bones of it!

After the usual `cmake && make && make install`, the user may now execute `make package` and `make package_source` to build the respective DEB binary package and DEB source package.

Unfortunately, my proof-of-concept isn't ready for a pull request just yet: the finished DEB package is missing the final executable (which is strange since all the other files and directories under _games_ is packaged), and the directory layout within the DEB package isn't quite right for proper installation.

By the way, I also ran into issue #1465 during `make install`; this issue isn't related to the DEB package support code, but I'm just giving a heads up on my experience since `make install` is required before `make package`. I was able to get past the issue by simply copying the **libSDL2-2.0.so.0.4.0** file from the _games_ directory to the _buildFiles/arch/Tools/CMake/sdl2_ directory and renaming it to **libSDL2.so**.

data.title: Crash! - new datablock from DefaultPlayerData.
data.body: The game crash when you create a new datablock and copy his data from DefaultPlayerData. Save, exit the level, and re-enter the level, it crash. To avoid the crash when you reenter the level is needed to clean your managedDatablocks.cs **Caused by:** Commits on Jun 2, 2016 - 89672ea **VS2015 log** show this from compiledEval.cpp **console.log** `tools/shapeEditor/main.cs (291): Unable to find object: '0' attempting to call function 'delete' 20867 -> deactivatePackages CDROP: 20869 IP:0.0.0.0:0 Exporting server prefs... Time spent in toggleEditor() : 0.297 s Exporting server prefs... SimGroup::addObject - (280440944) can't add self! Executing core/art/datablocks/datablockExec.cs. Executing core/art/datablocks/camera.cs. Executing core/art/datablocks/markers.cs. Executing core/art/datablocks/defaultparticle.cs. Executing art/ribbons/ribbonExec.cs. Executing art/ribbons/ribbons.cs. Executing art/particles/managedParticleData.cs. Executing art/particles/managedParticleEmitterData.cs. Executing art/decals/managedDecalData.cs. Executing art/datablocks/managedDatablocks.cs. Exception thrown: read access violation. currentNewObject-> was 0xDDDDDDDD.`

data.title: New object pointer cleanup
data.body:
Adds some pointer cleanup if we bail out of creating a new object for whatever reason, mostly pertainig to datablocks.

If we exit out and delete our object, we were had the possibility of currentNewObject pointing to a bad memory address, potentially causing a crash. The cleanup of the pointer on the delete by setting it to NULL prevents that.

data.title: Fixed compile errors on linux (obvious programming faults).
data.body: A bool is not a pointer and a reference has to be returned.
